speaker: ALBANY
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: ALBANY
text_entry: SCENE I. The king of Navarre's park.

speaker: ALBANY
text_entry: Enter FERDINAND king of Navarre, BIRON, LONGAVILLE and DUMAIN

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Let fame, that all hunt after in their lives,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Live register'd upon our brazen tombs

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: And then grace us in the disgrace of death;

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: When, spite of cormorant devouring Time,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: The endeavor of this present breath may buy

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: That honour which shall bate his scythe's keen edge

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: And make us heirs of all eternity.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Therefore, brave conquerors,--for so you are,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: That war against your own affections

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: And the huge army of the world's desires,--

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Our late edict shall strongly stand in force:

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Navarre shall be the wonder of the world;

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Our court shall be a little Academe,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Still and contemplative in living art.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: You three, Biron, Dumain, and Longaville,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Have sworn for three years' term to live with me

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: My fellow-scholars, and to keep those statutes

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: That are recorded in this schedule here:

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Your oaths are pass'd; and now subscribe your names,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: That his own hand may strike his honour down

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: That violates the smallest branch herein:

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: If you are arm'd to do as sworn to do,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Subscribe to your deep oaths, and keep it too.

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: I am resolved; 'tis but a three years' fast:

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: The mind shall banquet, though the body pine:

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: Fat paunches have lean pates, and dainty bits

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: Make rich the ribs, but bankrupt quite the wits.

speaker: DUMAIN
text_entry: My loving lord, Dumain is mortified:

speaker: DUMAIN
text_entry: The grosser manner of these world's delights

speaker: DUMAIN
text_entry: He throws upon the gross world's baser slaves:

speaker: DUMAIN
text_entry: To love, to wealth, to pomp, I pine and die;

speaker: DUMAIN
text_entry: With all these living in philosophy.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: I can but say their protestation over;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: So much, dear liege, I have already sworn,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: That is, to live and study here three years.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: But there are other strict observances;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: As, not to see a woman in that term,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Which I hope well is not enrolled there;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And one day in a week to touch no food

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And but one meal on every day beside,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: The which I hope is not enrolled there;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And then, to sleep but three hours in the night,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And not be seen to wink of all the day--

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: When I was wont to think no harm all night

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And make a dark night too of half the day--

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Which I hope well is not enrolled there:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: O, these are barren tasks, too hard to keep,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Not to see ladies, study, fast, not sleep!

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Your oath is pass'd to pass away from these.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Let me say no, my liege, an if you please:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: I only swore to study with your grace

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And stay here in your court for three years' space.

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: You swore to that, Biron, and to the rest.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: By yea and nay, sir, then I swore in jest.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: What is the end of study? let me know.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Why, that to know, which else we should not know.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Things hid and barr'd, you mean, from common sense?

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Ay, that is study's godlike recompense.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Come on, then; I will swear to study so,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: To know the thing I am forbid to know:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: As thus,--to study where I well may dine,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: When I to feast expressly am forbid;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Or study where to meet some mistress fine,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: When mistresses from common sense are hid;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Or, having sworn too hard a keeping oath,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Study to break it and not break my troth.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: If study's gain be thus and this be so,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Study knows that which yet it doth not know:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Swear me to this, and I will ne'er say no.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: These be the stops that hinder study quite

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: And train our intellects to vain delight.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Why, all delights are vain; but that most vain,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Which with pain purchased doth inherit pain:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: As, painfully to pore upon a book

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: To seek the light of truth; while truth the while

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Doth falsely blind the eyesight of his look:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Light seeking light doth light of light beguile:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: So, ere you find where light in darkness lies,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Your light grows dark by losing of your eyes.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Study me how to please the eye indeed

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: By fixing it upon a fairer eye,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Who dazzling so, that eye shall be his heed

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And give him light that it was blinded by.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Study is like the heaven's glorious sun

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: That will not be deep-search'd with saucy looks:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Small have continual plodders ever won

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Save base authority from others' books

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: These earthly godfathers of heaven's lights

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: That give a name to every fixed star

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Have no more profit of their shining nights

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Than those that walk and wot not what they are.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Too much to know is to know nought but fame;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And every godfather can give a name.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: How well he's read, to reason against reading!

speaker: DUMAIN
text_entry: Proceeded well, to stop all good proceeding!

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: He weeds the corn and still lets grow the weeding.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: The spring is near when green geese are a-breeding.

speaker: DUMAIN
text_entry: How follows that?

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Fit in his place and time.

speaker: DUMAIN
text_entry: In reason nothing.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Something then in rhyme.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Biron is like an envious sneaping frost,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: That bites the first-born infants of the spring.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Well, say I am; why should proud summer boast

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Before the birds have any cause to sing?

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Why should I joy in any abortive birth?

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: At Christmas I no more desire a rose

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Than wish a snow in May's new-fangled mirth;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: But like of each thing that in season grows.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: So you, to study now it is too late,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Climb o'er the house to unlock the little gate.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Well, sit you out: go home, Biron: adieu.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: No, my good lord; I have sworn to stay with you:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And though I have for barbarism spoke more

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Than for that angel knowledge you can say,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Yet confident I'll keep what I have swore

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And bide the penance of each three years' day.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Give me the paper; let me read the same;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And to the strict'st decrees I'll write my name.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: How well this yielding rescues thee from shame!

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: [Reads]  'Item, That no woman shall come within a

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: mile of my court:' Hath this been proclaimed?

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: Four days ago.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Let's see the penalty.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Reads

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: 'On pain of losing her tongue.' Who devised this penalty?

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: Marry, that did I.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Sweet lord, and why?

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: To fright them hence with that dread penalty.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: A dangerous law against gentility!

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Reads

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: 'Item, If any man be seen to talk with a woman

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: within the term of three years, he shall endure such

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: public shame as the rest of the court can possibly devise.'

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: This article, my liege, yourself must break;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: For well you know here comes in embassy

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: The French king's daughter with yourself to speak--

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: A maid of grace and complete majesty--

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: About surrender up of Aquitaine

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: To her decrepit, sick and bedrid father:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Therefore this article is made in vain,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Or vainly comes the admired princess hither.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: What say you, lords? Why, this was quite forgot.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: So study evermore is overshot:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: While it doth study to have what it would

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: It doth forget to do the thing it should,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And when it hath the thing it hunteth most,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: 'Tis won as towns with fire, so won, so lost.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: We must of force dispense with this decree;

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: She must lie here on mere necessity.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Necessity will make us all forsworn

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Three thousand times within this three years' space;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: For every man with his affects is born,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Not by might master'd but by special grace:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: If I break faith, this word shall speak for me;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: I am forsworn on 'mere necessity.'

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: So to the laws at large I write my name:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Subscribes

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And he that breaks them in the least degree

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Stands in attainder of eternal shame:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Suggestions are to other as to me;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: But I believe, although I seem so loath,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: I am the last that will last keep his oath.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: But is there no quick recreation granted?

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Ay, that there is. Our court, you know, is haunted

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: With a refined traveller of Spain;

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: A man in all the world's new fashion planted,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: That hath a mint of phrases in his brain;

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: One whom the music of his own vain tongue

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Doth ravish like enchanting harmony;

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: A man of complements, whom right and wrong

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Have chose as umpire of their mutiny:

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: This child of fancy, that Armado hight,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: For interim to our studies shall relate

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: In high-born words the worth of many a knight

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: From tawny Spain lost in the world's debate.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: How you delight, my lords, I know not, I;

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: But, I protest, I love to hear him lie

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: And I will use him for my minstrelsy.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Armado is a most illustrious wight,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: A man of fire-new words, fashion's own knight.

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: Costard the swain and he shall be our sport;

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: And so to study, three years is but short.

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: Enter DULL with a letter, and COSTARD

speaker: DULL
text_entry: Which is the duke's own person?

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: This, fellow: what wouldst?

speaker: DULL
text_entry: I myself reprehend his own person, for I am his

speaker: DULL
text_entry: grace's tharborough: but I would see his own person

speaker: DULL
text_entry: in flesh and blood.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: This is he.

speaker: DULL
text_entry: Signior Arme--Arme--commends you. There's villany

speaker: DULL
text_entry: abroad: this letter will tell you more.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Sir, the contempts thereof are as touching me.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: A letter from the magnificent Armado.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: How low soever the matter, I hope in God for high words.

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: A high hope for a low heaven: God grant us patience!

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: To hear? or forbear laughing?

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: To hear meekly, sir, and to laugh moderately; or to

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: forbear both.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Well, sir, be it as the style shall give us cause to

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: climb in the merriness.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: The matter is to me, sir, as concerning Jaquenetta.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: The manner of it is, I was taken with the manner.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: In what manner?

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: In manner and form following, sir; all those three:

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: I was seen with her in the manor-house, sitting with

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: her upon the form, and taken following her into the

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: park; which, put together, is in manner and form

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: following. Now, sir, for the manner,--it is the

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: manner of a man to speak to a woman: for the form,--

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: in some form.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: For the following, sir?

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: As it shall follow in my correction: and God defend

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: the right!

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Will you hear this letter with attention?

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: As we would hear an oracle.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Such is the simplicity of man to hearken after the flesh.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: [Reads]  'Great deputy, the welkin's vicegerent and

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: sole dominator of Navarre, my soul's earth's god,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: and body's fostering patron.'

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Not a word of Costard yet.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: [Reads]  'So it is,'--

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: It may be so: but if he say it is so, he is, in

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: telling true, but so.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Peace!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Be to me and every man that dares not fight!

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: No words!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Of other men's secrets, I beseech you.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: [Reads]  'So it is, besieged with sable-coloured

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: melancholy, I did commend the black-oppressing humour

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: to the most wholesome physic of thy health-giving

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: air; and, as I am a gentleman, betook myself to

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: walk. The time when. About the sixth hour; when

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: beasts most graze, birds best peck, and men sit down

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: to that nourishment which is called supper: so much

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: for the time when. Now for the ground which; which,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: I mean, I walked upon: it is y-cleped thy park. Then

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: for the place where; where, I mean, I did encounter

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: that obscene and preposterous event, that draweth

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: from my snow-white pen the ebon-coloured ink, which

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: here thou viewest, beholdest, surveyest, or seest;

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: but to the place where; it standeth north-north-east

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: and by east from the west corner of thy curious-

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: knotted garden: there did I see that low-spirited

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: swain, that base minnow of thy mirth,'--

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Me?

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: [Reads]  'that unlettered small-knowing soul,'--

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Me?

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: [Reads]  'that shallow vassal,'--

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Still me?

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: [Reads]  'which, as I remember, hight Costard,'--

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: O, me!

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: [Reads]  'sorted and consorted, contrary to thy

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: established proclaimed edict and continent canon,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: which with,--O, with--but with this I passion to say

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: wherewith,--

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: With a wench.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: [Reads]  'with a child of our grandmother Eve, a

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: female; or, for thy more sweet understanding, a

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: woman. Him I, as my ever-esteemed duty pricks me on,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: have sent to thee, to receive the meed of

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: punishment, by thy sweet grace's officer, Anthony

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Dull; a man of good repute, carriage, bearing, and

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: estimation.'

speaker: DULL
text_entry: 'Me, an't shall please you; I am Anthony Dull.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: [Reads]  'For Jaquenetta,--so is the weaker vessel

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: called which I apprehended with the aforesaid

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: swain,--I keep her as a vessel of the law's fury;

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: and shall, at the least of thy sweet notice, bring

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: her to trial. Thine, in all compliments of devoted

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: and heart-burning heat of duty.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO.'

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: This is not so well as I looked for, but the best

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: that ever I heard.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Ay, the best for the worst. But, sirrah, what say

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: you to this?

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Sir, I confess the wench.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Did you hear the proclamation?

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: I do confess much of the hearing it but little of

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: the marking of it.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: It was proclaimed a year's imprisonment, to be taken

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: with a wench.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: I was taken with none, sir: I was taken with a damsel.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Well, it was proclaimed 'damsel.'

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: This was no damsel, neither, sir; she was a virgin.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: It is so varied, too; for it was proclaimed 'virgin.'

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: If it were, I deny her virginity: I was taken with a maid.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: This maid will not serve your turn, sir.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: This maid will serve my turn, sir.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Sir, I will pronounce your sentence: you shall fast

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: a week with bran and water.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: I had rather pray a month with mutton and porridge.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: And Don Armado shall be your keeper.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: My Lord Biron, see him deliver'd o'er:

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: And go we, lords, to put in practise that

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Which each to other hath so strongly sworn.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Exeunt FERDINAND, LONGAVILLE, and DUMAIN

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: I'll lay my head to any good man's hat,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: These oaths and laws will prove an idle scorn.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Sirrah, come on.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: I suffer for the truth, sir; for true it is, I was

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: taken with Jaquenetta, and Jaquenetta is a true

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: girl; and therefore welcome the sour cup of

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: prosperity! Affliction may one day smile again; and

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: till then, sit thee down, sorrow!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: LOVE'S LABOURS LOST

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: SCENE II. The same.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Enter DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO and MOTH

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Boy, what sign is it when a man of great spirit

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: grows melancholy?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: A great sign, sir, that he will look sad.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Why, sadness is one and the self-same thing, dear imp.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: No, no; O Lord, sir, no.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: How canst thou part sadness and melancholy, my

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: tender juvenal?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: By a familiar demonstration of the working, my tough senior.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Why tough senior? why tough senior?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Why tender juvenal? why tender juvenal?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: I spoke it, tender juvenal, as a congruent epitheton

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: appertaining to thy young days, which we may

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: nominate tender.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: And I, tough senior, as an appertinent title to your

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: old time, which we may name tough.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON ADRIANO DE

speaker: ARMADO
text_entry: Pretty and apt.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: How mean you, sir? I pretty, and my saying apt? or

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: I apt, and my saying pretty?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Thou pretty, because little.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Little pretty, because little. Wherefore apt?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: And therefore apt, because quick.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Speak you this in my praise, master?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: In thy condign praise.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: I will praise an eel with the same praise.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: What, that an eel is ingenious?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: That an eel is quick.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: I do say thou art quick in answers: thou heatest my blood.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: I am answered, sir.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: I love not to be crossed.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: [Aside]  He speaks the mere contrary; crosses love not him.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: I have promised to study three years with the duke.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: You may do it in an hour, sir.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Impossible.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: How many is one thrice told?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: I am ill at reckoning; it fitteth the spirit of a tapster.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: You are a gentleman and a gamester, sir.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: I confess both: they are both the varnish of a

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: complete man.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Then, I am sure, you know how much the gross sum of

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: deuce-ace amounts to.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: It doth amount to one more than two.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Which the base vulgar do call three.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: True.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Why, sir, is this such a piece of study? Now here

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: is three studied, ere ye'll thrice wink: and how

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: easy it is to put 'years' to the word 'three,' and

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: study three years in two words, the dancing horse

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: will tell you.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: A most fine figure!

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: To prove you a cipher.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: I will hereupon confess I am in love: and as it is

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: base for a soldier to love, so am I in love with a

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: base wench. If drawing my sword against the humour

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: of affection would deliver me from the reprobate

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: thought of it, I would take Desire prisoner, and

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: ransom him to any French courtier for a new-devised

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: courtesy. I think scorn to sigh: methinks I should

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: outswear Cupid. Comfort, me, boy: what great men

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: have been in love?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Hercules, master.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Most sweet Hercules! More authority, dear boy, name

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: more; and, sweet my child, let them be men of good

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: repute and carriage.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Samson, master: he was a man of good carriage, great

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: carriage, for he carried the town-gates on his back

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: like a porter: and he was in love.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: O well-knit Samson! strong-jointed Samson! I do

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: excel thee in my rapier as much as thou didst me in

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: carrying gates. I am in love too. Who was Samson's

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: love, my dear Moth?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: A woman, master.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Of what complexion?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Of all the four, or the three, or the two, or one of the four.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Tell me precisely of what complexion.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Of the sea-water green, sir.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Is that one of the four complexions?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: As I have read, sir; and the best of them too.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Green indeed is the colour of lovers; but to have a

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: love of that colour, methinks Samson had small reason

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: for it. He surely affected her for her wit.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: It was so, sir; for she had a green wit.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: My love is most immaculate white and red.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Most maculate thoughts, master, are masked under

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: such colours.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Define, define, well-educated infant.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: My father's wit and my mother's tongue, assist me!

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Sweet invocation of a child; most pretty and

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: pathetical!

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: If she be made of white and red,

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Her faults will ne'er be known,

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: For blushing cheeks by faults are bred

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: And fears by pale white shown:

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Then if she fear, or be to blame,

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: By this you shall not know,

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: For still her cheeks possess the same

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Which native she doth owe.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: A dangerous rhyme, master, against the reason of

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: white and red.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Is there not a ballad, boy, of the King and the Beggar?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: The world was very guilty of such a ballad some

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: three ages since: but I think now 'tis not to be

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: found; or, if it were, it would neither serve for

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: the writing nor the tune.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: I will have that subject newly writ o'er, that I may

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: example my digression by some mighty precedent.

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Boy, I do love that country girl that I took in the

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: park with the rational hind Costard: she deserves well.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: [Aside]  To be whipped; and yet a better love than

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: my master.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Sing, boy; my spirit grows heavy in love.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: And that's great marvel, loving a light wench.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: I say, sing.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Forbear till this company be past.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Enter DULL, COSTARD, and JAQUENETTA

speaker: DULL
text_entry: Sir, the duke's pleasure is, that you keep Costard

speaker: DULL
text_entry: safe: and you must suffer him to take no delight

speaker: DULL
text_entry: nor no penance; but a' must fast three days a week.

speaker: DULL
text_entry: For this damsel, I must keep her at the park: she

speaker: DULL
text_entry: is allowed for the day-woman. Fare you well.

speaker: DULL
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: I do betray myself with blushing. Maid!

speaker: JAQUENETTA
text_entry: Man?

speaker: JAQUENETTA
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: I will visit thee at the lodge.

speaker: JAQUENETTA
text_entry: That's hereby.

speaker: JAQUENETTA
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: I know where it is situate.

speaker: JAQUENETTA
text_entry: Lord, how wise you are!

speaker: JAQUENETTA
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: I will tell thee wonders.

speaker: JAQUENETTA
text_entry: With that face?

speaker: JAQUENETTA
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: I love thee.

speaker: JAQUENETTA
text_entry: So I heard you say.

speaker: JAQUENETTA
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: And so, farewell.

speaker: JAQUENETTA
text_entry: Fair weather after you!

speaker: DULL
text_entry: Come, Jaquenetta, away!

speaker: DULL
text_entry: Exeunt DULL and JAQUENETTA

speaker: DULL
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Villain, thou shalt fast for thy offences ere thou

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: be pardoned.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Well, sir, I hope, when I do it, I shall do it on a

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: full stomach.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Thou shalt be heavily punished.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: I am more bound to you than your fellows, for they

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: are but lightly rewarded.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Take away this villain; shut him up.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Come, you transgressing slave; away!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Let me not be pent up, sir: I will fast, being loose.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: No, sir; that were fast and loose: thou shalt to prison.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Well, if ever I do see the merry days of desolation

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: that I have seen, some shall see.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: What shall some see?

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Nay, nothing, Master Moth, but what they look upon.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: It is not for prisoners to be too silent in their

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: words; and therefore I will say nothing: I thank

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: God I have as little patience as another man; and

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: therefore I can be quiet.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Exeunt MOTH and COSTARD

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: I do affect the very ground, which is base, where

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: her shoe, which is baser, guided by her foot, which

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: is basest, doth tread. I shall be forsworn, which

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: is a great argument of falsehood, if I love. And

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: how can that be true love which is falsely

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: attempted? Love is a familiar; Love is a devil:

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: there is no evil angel but Love. Yet was Samson so

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: tempted, and he had an excellent strength; yet was

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Solomon so seduced, and he had a very good wit.

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Cupid's butt-shaft is too hard for Hercules' club;

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: and therefore too much odds for a Spaniard's rapier.

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: The first and second cause will not serve my turn;

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: the passado he respects not, the duello he regards

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: not: his disgrace is to be called boy; but his

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: glory is to subdue men. Adieu, valour! rust rapier!

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: be still, drum! for your manager is in love; yea,

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: he loveth. Assist me, some extemporal god of rhyme,

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: for I am sure I shall turn sonnet. Devise, wit;

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: write, pen; for I am for whole volumes in folio.

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: LOVE'S LABOURS LOST

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: ACT II

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: SCENE I. The same.

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Enter the PRINCESS of France, ROSALINE, MARIA, KATHARINE, BOYET, Lords, and other Attendants

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Now, madam, summon up your dearest spirits:

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Consider who the king your father sends,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: To whom he sends, and what's his embassy:

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Yourself, held precious in the world's esteem,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: To parley with the sole inheritor

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Of all perfections that a man may owe,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Matchless Navarre; the plea of no less weight

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Than Aquitaine, a dowry for a queen.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Be now as prodigal of all dear grace

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: As Nature was in making graces dear

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: When she did starve the general world beside

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: And prodigally gave them all to you.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Good Lord Boyet, my beauty, though but mean,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Needs not the painted flourish of your praise:

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Beauty is bought by judgement of the eye,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Not utter'd by base sale of chapmen's tongues:

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: I am less proud to hear you tell my worth

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Than you much willing to be counted wise

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: In spending your wit in the praise of mine.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: But now to task the tasker: good Boyet,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: You are not ignorant, all-telling fame

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Doth noise abroad, Navarre hath made a vow,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Till painful study shall outwear three years,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: No woman may approach his silent court:

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Therefore to's seemeth it a needful course,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Before we enter his forbidden gates,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: To know his pleasure; and in that behalf,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Bold of your worthiness, we single you

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: As our best-moving fair solicitor.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Tell him, the daughter of the King of France,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: On serious business, craving quick dispatch,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Importunes personal conference with his grace:

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Haste, signify so much; while we attend,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Like humble-visaged suitors, his high will.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Proud of employment, willingly I go.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: All pride is willing pride, and yours is so.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Exit BOYET

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Who are the votaries, my loving lords,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: That are vow-fellows with this virtuous duke?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Lord Longaville is one.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Know you the man?

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: I know him, madam: at a marriage-feast,

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Between Lord Perigort and the beauteous heir

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Of Jaques Falconbridge, solemnized

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: In Normandy, saw I this Longaville:

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: A man of sovereign parts he is esteem'd;

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Well fitted in arts, glorious in arms:

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Nothing becomes him ill that he would well.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: The only soil of his fair virtue's gloss,

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: If virtue's gloss will stain with any soil,

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Is a sharp wit matched with too blunt a will;

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Whose edge hath power to cut, whose will still wills

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: It should none spare that come within his power.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Some merry mocking lord, belike; is't so?

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: They say so most that most his humours know.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Such short-lived wits do wither as they grow.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Who are the rest?

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: The young Dumain, a well-accomplished youth,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Of all that virtue love for virtue loved:

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Most power to do most harm, least knowing ill;

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: For he hath wit to make an ill shape good,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: And shape to win grace though he had no wit.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: I saw him at the Duke Alencon's once;

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: And much too little of that good I saw

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Is my report to his great worthiness.

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Another of these students at that time

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Was there with him, if I have heard a truth.

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Biron they call him; but a merrier man,

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Within the limit of becoming mirth,

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: I never spent an hour's talk withal:

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: His eye begets occasion for his wit;

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: For every object that the one doth catch

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: The other turns to a mirth-moving jest,

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Which his fair tongue, conceit's expositor,

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Delivers in such apt and gracious words

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: That aged ears play truant at his tales

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: And younger hearings are quite ravished;

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: So sweet and voluble is his discourse.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: God bless my ladies! are they all in love,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: That every one her own hath garnished

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: With such bedecking ornaments of praise?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Here comes Boyet.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Re-enter BOYET

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Now, what admittance, lord?

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Navarre had notice of your fair approach;

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: And he and his competitors in oath

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Were all address'd to meet you, gentle lady,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Before I came. Marry, thus much I have learnt:

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: He rather means to lodge you in the field,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Like one that comes here to besiege his court,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Than seek a dispensation for his oath,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: To let you enter his unpeopled house.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Here comes Navarre.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Enter FERDINAND, LONGAVILLE, DUMAIN, BIRON, and Attendants

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Fair princess, welcome to the court of Navarre.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: 'Fair' I give you back again; and 'welcome' I have

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: not yet: the roof of this court is too high to be

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: yours; and welcome to the wide fields too base to be mine.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: You shall be welcome, madam, to my court.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: I will be welcome, then: conduct me thither.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Hear me, dear lady; I have sworn an oath.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Our Lady help my lord! he'll be forsworn.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Not for the world, fair madam, by my will.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Why, will shall break it; will and nothing else.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Your ladyship is ignorant what it is.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Were my lord so, his ignorance were wise,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Where now his knowledge must prove ignorance.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: I hear your grace hath sworn out house-keeping:

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Tis deadly sin to keep that oath, my lord,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: And sin to break it.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: But pardon me. I am too sudden-bold:

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: To teach a teacher ill beseemeth me.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Vouchsafe to read the purpose of my coming,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: And suddenly resolve me in my suit.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Madam, I will, if suddenly I may.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: You will the sooner, that I were away;

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: For you'll prove perjured if you make me stay.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Did not I dance with you in Brabant once?

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Did not I dance with you in Brabant once?

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: I know you did.

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: How needless was it then to ask the question!

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: You must not be so quick.

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: 'Tis 'long of you that spur me with such questions.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Your wit's too hot, it speeds too fast, 'twill tire.

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Not till it leave the rider in the mire.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: What time o' day?

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: The hour that fools should ask.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Now fair befall your mask!

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Fair fall the face it covers!

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And send you many lovers!

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Amen, so you be none.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Nay, then will I be gone.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Madam, your father here doth intimate

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: The payment of a hundred thousand crowns;

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Being but the one half of an entire sum

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Disbursed by my father in his wars.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: But say that he or we, as neither have,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Received that sum, yet there remains unpaid

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: A hundred thousand more; in surety of the which,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: One part of Aquitaine is bound to us,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Although not valued to the money's worth.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: If then the king your father will restore

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: But that one half which is unsatisfied,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: We will give up our right in Aquitaine,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: And hold fair friendship with his majesty.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: But that, it seems, he little purposeth,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: For here he doth demand to have repaid

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: A hundred thousand crowns; and not demands,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: On payment of a hundred thousand crowns,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: To have his title live in Aquitaine;

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Which we much rather had depart withal

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: And have the money by our father lent

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Than Aquitaine so gelded as it is.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Dear Princess, were not his requests so far

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: From reason's yielding, your fair self should make

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: A yielding 'gainst some reason in my breast

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: And go well satisfied to France again.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: You do the king my father too much wrong

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: And wrong the reputation of your name,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: In so unseeming to confess receipt

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Of that which hath so faithfully been paid.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: I do protest I never heard of it;

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: And if you prove it, I'll repay it back

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Or yield up Aquitaine.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: We arrest your word.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Boyet, you can produce acquittances

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: For such a sum from special officers

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Of Charles his father.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Satisfy me so.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: So please your grace, the packet is not come

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Where that and other specialties are bound:

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: To-morrow you shall have a sight of them.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: It shall suffice me: at which interview

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: All liberal reason I will yield unto.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Meantime receive such welcome at my hand

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: As honour without breach of honour may

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Make tender of to thy true worthiness:

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: You may not come, fair princess, in my gates;

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: But here without you shall be so received

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: As you shall deem yourself lodged in my heart,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Though so denied fair harbour in my house.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Your own good thoughts excuse me, and farewell:

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: To-morrow shall we visit you again.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Sweet health and fair desires consort your grace!

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Thy own wish wish I thee in every place!

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Lady, I will commend you to mine own heart.

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Pray you, do my commendations; I would be glad to see it.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: I would you heard it groan.

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Is the fool sick?

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Sick at the heart.

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Alack, let it blood.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Would that do it good?

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: My physic says 'ay.'

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Will you prick't with your eye?

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: No point, with my knife.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Now, God save thy life!

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: And yours from long living!

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: I cannot stay thanksgiving.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Retiring

speaker: DUMAIN
text_entry: Sir, I pray you, a word: what lady is that same?

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: The heir of Alencon, Katharine her name.

speaker: DUMAIN
text_entry: A gallant lady. Monsieur, fare you well.

speaker: DUMAIN
text_entry: Exit

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: I beseech you a word: what is she in the white?

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: A woman sometimes, an you saw her in the light.

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: Perchance light in the light. I desire her name.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: She hath but one for herself; to desire that were a shame.

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: Pray you, sir, whose daughter?

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Her mother's, I have heard.

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: God's blessing on your beard!

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Good sir, be not offended.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: She is an heir of Falconbridge.

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: Nay, my choler is ended.

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: She is a most sweet lady.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Not unlike, sir, that may be.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Exit LONGAVILLE

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: What's her name in the cap?

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Rosaline, by good hap.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Is she wedded or no?

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: To her will, sir, or so.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: You are welcome, sir: adieu.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Farewell to me, sir, and welcome to you.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Exit BIRON

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: That last is Biron, the merry madcap lord:

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Not a word with him but a jest.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: And every jest but a word.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: It was well done of you to take him at his word.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: I was as willing to grapple as he was to board.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Two hot sheeps, marry.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: And wherefore not ships?

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: No sheep, sweet lamb, unless we feed on your lips.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: You sheep, and I pasture: shall that finish the jest?

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: So you grant pasture for me.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Offering to kiss her

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Not so, gentle beast:

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: My lips are no common, though several they be.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Belonging to whom?

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: To my fortunes and me.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Good wits will be jangling; but, gentles, agree:

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: This civil war of wits were much better used

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: On Navarre and his book-men; for here 'tis abused.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: If my observation, which very seldom lies,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: By the heart's still rhetoric disclosed with eyes,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Deceive me not now, Navarre is infected.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: With what?

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: With that which we lovers entitle affected.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Your reason?

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Why, all his behaviors did make their retire

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: To the court of his eye, peeping thorough desire:

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: His heart, like an agate, with your print impress'd,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Proud with his form, in his eye pride express'd:

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: His tongue, all impatient to speak and not see,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Did stumble with haste in his eyesight to be;

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: All senses to that sense did make their repair,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: To feel only looking on fairest of fair:

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Methought all his senses were lock'd in his eye,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: As jewels in crystal for some prince to buy;

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Who, tendering their own worth from where they were glass'd,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Did point you to buy them, along as you pass'd:

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: His face's own margent did quote such amazes

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: That all eyes saw his eyes enchanted with gazes.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: I'll give you Aquitaine and all that is his,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: An you give him for my sake but one loving kiss.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Come to our pavilion: Boyet is disposed.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: But to speak that in words which his eye hath

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: disclosed.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: I only have made a mouth of his eye,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: By adding a tongue which I know will not lie.

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Thou art an old love-monger and speakest skilfully.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: He is Cupid's grandfather and learns news of him.

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Then was Venus like her mother, for her father is but grim.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Do you hear, my mad wenches?

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: No.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: What then, do you see?

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Ay, our way to be gone.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: You are too hard for me.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: BOYET

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Warble, child; make passionate my sense of hearing.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Concolinel.

speaker: MOTH

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Sweet air! Go, tenderness of years; take this key,

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

text_entry: How meanest thou? brawling in French?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: No, my complete master: but to jig off a tune at

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: the tongue's end, canary to it with your feet, humour

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: it with turning up your eyelids, sigh a note and

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: sing a note, sometime through the throat, as if you

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: swallowed love with singing love, sometime through

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: the nose, as if you snuffed up love by smelling

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: love; with your hat penthouse-like o'er the shop of

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: your eyes; with your arms crossed on your thin-belly

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: doublet like a rabbit on a spit; or your hands in

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: your pocket like a man after the old painting; and

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: keep not too long in one tune, but a snip and away.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: These are complements, these are humours; these

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: betray nice wenches, that would be betrayed without

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: these; and make them men of note--do you note

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: me?--that most are affected to these.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

text_entry: How hast thou purchased this experience?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: By my penny of observation.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: But O,--but O,--

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: 'The hobby-horse is forgot.'

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

text_entry: Callest thou my love 'hobby-horse'?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: No, master; the hobby-horse is but a colt, and your

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: love perhaps a hackney. But have you forgot your love?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Almost I had.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Negligent student! learn her by heart.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: By heart and in heart, boy.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: And out of heart, master: all those three I will prove.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: What wilt thou prove?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: A man, if I live; and this, by, in, and without, upon

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: the instant: by heart you love her, because your

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: heart cannot come by her; in heart you love her,

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: because your heart is in love with her; and out of

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: heart you love her, being out of heart that you

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: cannot enjoy her.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: I am all these three.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: And three times as much more, and yet nothing at

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: all.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Fetch hither the swain: he must carry me a letter.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: A message well sympathized; a horse to be ambassador

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: for an ass.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Ha, ha! what sayest thou?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Marry, sir, you must send the ass upon the horse,

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: for he is very slow-gaited. But I go.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: The way is but short: away!

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: As swift as lead, sir.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: The meaning, pretty ingenious?

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Is not lead a metal heavy, dull, and slow?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Minime, honest master; or rather, master, no.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: I say lead is slow.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: You are too swift, sir, to say so:

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Is that lead slow which is fired from a gun?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Sweet smoke of rhetoric!

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: He reputes me a cannon; and the bullet, that's he:

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: I shoot thee at the swain.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Thump then and I flee.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Exit

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: A most acute juvenal; voluble and free of grace!

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: By thy favour, sweet welkin, I must sigh in thy face:

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Most rude melancholy, valour gives thee place.

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: My herald is return'd.

text_entry: Some enigma, some riddle: come, thy l'envoy; begin.

text_entry: No enigma, no riddle, no l'envoy; no salve in the

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: mail, sir: O, sir, plantain, a plain plantain! no

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: l'envoy, no l'envoy; no salve, sir, but a plantain!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: By virtue, thou enforcest laughter; thy silly

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: thought my spleen; the heaving of my lungs provokes

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: me to ridiculous smiling. O, pardon me, my stars!

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Doth the inconsiderate take salve for l'envoy, and

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: the word l'envoy for a salve?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Do the wise think them other? is not l'envoy a salve?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: No, page: it is an epilogue or discourse, to make plain

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: I will example it:

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: The fox, the ape, and the humble-bee,

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Were still at odds, being but three.

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: The fox, the ape, and the humble-bee,

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Were still at odds, being but three.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Until the goose came out of door,

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: And stay'd the odds by adding four.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Now will I begin your moral, and do you follow with

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: my l'envoy.

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: The fox, the ape, and the humble-bee,

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: Were still at odds, being but three.

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Until the goose came out of door,

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Staying the odds by adding four.

speaker: MOTH

text_entry: The boy hath sold him a bargain, a goose, that's flat.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Sir, your pennyworth is good, an your goose be fat.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: To sell a bargain well is as cunning as fast and loose:

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Let me see; a fat l'envoy; ay, that's a fat goose.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: Come hither, come hither. How did this argument begin?

speaker: MOTH
text_entry: By saying that a costard was broken in a shin.

text_entry: Then call'd you for the l'envoy.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: True, and I for a plantain: thus came your

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: argument in;

text_entry: Then the boy's fat l'envoy, the goose that you bought;

text_entry: But tell me; how was there a costard broken in a shin?

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Thou hast no feeling of it, Moth: I will speak that l'envoy:

speaker: COSTARD

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO

text_entry: DON

text_entry: O, marry me to one Frances: I smell some l'envoy,

speaker: COSTARD

text_entry: DON

text_entry: enfreedoming thy person; thou wert immured,

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO

text_entry: DON

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO
text_entry: bear this significant

speaker: ADRIANO DE ARMADO

speaker: COSTARD

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: farthings--remuneration.--'What's the price of this

text_entry: Enter BIRON

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: O, my good knave Costard! exceedingly well met.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Pray you, sir, how much carnation ribbon may a man

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: buy for a remuneration?

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: What is a remuneration?

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Marry, sir, halfpenny farthing.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Why, then, three-farthing worth of silk.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: I thank your worship: God be wi' you!

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Stay, slave; I must employ thee:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: As thou wilt win my favour, good my knave,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Do one thing for me that I shall entreat.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: When would you have it done, sir?

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: This afternoon.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Well, I will do it, sir: fare you well.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Thou knowest not what it is.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: I shall know, sir, when I have done it.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Why, villain, thou must know first.

speaker: COSTARD
