text_entry: It must be done this afternoon.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Hark, slave, it is but this:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: The princess comes to hunt here in the park,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And in her train there is a gentle lady;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: When tongues speak sweetly, then they name her name,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And Rosaline they call her: ask for her;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And to her white hand see thou do commend

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: This seal'd-up counsel. There's thy guerdon; go.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Giving him a shilling

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Gardon, O sweet gardon! better than remuneration,

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: a'leven-pence farthing better: most sweet gardon! I

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: will do it sir, in print. Gardon! Remuneration!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And I, forsooth, in love! I, that have been love's whip;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: A very beadle to a humorous sigh;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: A critic, nay, a night-watch constable;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: A domineering pedant o'er the boy;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Than whom no mortal so magnificent!

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: This whimpled, whining, purblind, wayward boy;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: This senior-junior, giant-dwarf, Dan Cupid;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Regent of love-rhymes, lord of folded arms,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: The anointed sovereign of sighs and groans,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Liege of all loiterers and malcontents,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Dread prince of plackets, king of codpieces,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Sole imperator and great general

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Of trotting 'paritors:--O my little heart:--

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And I to be a corporal of his field,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And wear his colours like a tumbler's hoop!

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: What, I! I love! I sue! I seek a wife!

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: A woman, that is like a German clock,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Still a-repairing, ever out of frame,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And never going aright, being a watch,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: But being watch'd that it may still go right!

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Nay, to be perjured, which is worst of all;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And, among three, to love the worst of all;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: A wightly wanton with a velvet brow,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: With two pitch-balls stuck in her face for eyes;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Ay, and by heaven, one that will do the deed

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Though Argus were her eunuch and her guard:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And I to sigh for her! to watch for her!

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: To pray for her! Go to; it is a plague

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: That Cupid will impose for my neglect

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Of his almighty dreadful little might.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Well, I will love, write, sigh, pray, sue and groan:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Some men must love my lady and some Joan.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: LOVE'S LABOURS LOST

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: SCENE I. The same.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Enter the PRINCESS, and her train, a Forester, BOYET, ROSALINE, MARIA, and KATHARINE

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Was that the king, that spurred his horse so hard

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Against the steep uprising of the hill?

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: I know not; but I think it was not he.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Whoe'er a' was, a' show'd a mounting mind.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Well, lords, to-day we shall have our dispatch:

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: On Saturday we will return to France.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Then, forester, my friend, where is the bush

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: That we must stand and play the murderer in?

speaker: Forester
text_entry: Hereby, upon the edge of yonder coppice;

speaker: Forester
text_entry: A stand where you may make the fairest shoot.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: I thank my beauty, I am fair that shoot,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: And thereupon thou speak'st the fairest shoot.

speaker: Forester
text_entry: Pardon me, madam, for I meant not so.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: What, what? first praise me and again say no?

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: O short-lived pride! Not fair? alack for woe!

speaker: Forester
text_entry: Yes, madam, fair.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Nay, never paint me now:

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Where fair is not, praise cannot mend the brow.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Here, good my glass, take this for telling true:

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Fair payment for foul words is more than due.

speaker: Forester
text_entry: Nothing but fair is that which you inherit.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: See see, my beauty will be saved by merit!

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: O heresy in fair, fit for these days!

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: A giving hand, though foul, shall have fair praise.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: But come, the bow: now mercy goes to kill,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: And shooting well is then accounted ill.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Thus will I save my credit in the shoot:

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Not wounding, pity would not let me do't;

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: If wounding, then it was to show my skill,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: That more for praise than purpose meant to kill.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: And out of question so it is sometimes,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Glory grows guilty of detested crimes,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: When, for fame's sake, for praise, an outward part,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: We bend to that the working of the heart;

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: As I for praise alone now seek to spill

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: The poor deer's blood, that my heart means no ill.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Do not curst wives hold that self-sovereignty

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Only for praise sake, when they strive to be

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Lords o'er their lords?

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Only for praise: and praise we may afford

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: To any lady that subdues a lord.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Here comes a member of the commonwealth.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Enter COSTARD

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: God dig-you-den all! Pray you, which is the head lady?

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Thou shalt know her, fellow, by the rest that have no heads.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Which is the greatest lady, the highest?

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: The thickest and the tallest.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: The thickest and the tallest! it is so; truth is truth.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: An your waist, mistress, were as slender as my wit,

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: One o' these maids' girdles for your waist should be fit.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Are not you the chief woman? you are the thickest here.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: What's your will, sir? what's your will?

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: I have a letter from Monsieur Biron to one Lady Rosaline.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: O, thy letter, thy letter! he's a good friend of mine:

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Stand aside, good bearer. Boyet, you can carve;

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Break up this capon.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: I am bound to serve.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: This letter is mistook, it importeth none here;

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: It is writ to Jaquenetta.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: We will read it, I swear.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Break the neck of the wax, and every one give ear.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Reads

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: 'By heaven, that thou art fair, is most infallible;

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: true, that thou art beauteous; truth itself, that

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: thou art lovely. More fairer than fair, beautiful

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: than beauteous, truer than truth itself, have

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: commiseration on thy heroical vassal! The

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: magnanimous and most illustrate king Cophetua set

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: eye upon the pernicious and indubitate beggar

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Zenelophon; and he it was that might rightly say,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Veni, vidi, vici; which to annothanize in the

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: vulgar,--O base and obscure vulgar!--videlicet, He

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: came, saw, and overcame: he came, one; saw two;

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: overcame, three. Who came? the king: why did he

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: come? to see: why did he see? to overcome: to

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: whom came he? to the beggar: what saw he? the

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: beggar: who overcame he? the beggar. The

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: conclusion is victory: on whose side? the king's.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: The captive is enriched: on whose side? the

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: beggar's. The catastrophe is a nuptial: on whose

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: side? the king's: no, on both in one, or one in

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: both. I am the king; for so stands the comparison:

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: thou the beggar; for so witnesseth thy lowliness.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Shall I command thy love? I may: shall I enforce

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: thy love? I could: shall I entreat thy love? I

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: will. What shalt thou exchange for rags? robes;

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: for tittles? titles; for thyself? me. Thus,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: expecting thy reply, I profane my lips on thy foot,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: my eyes on thy picture. and my heart on thy every

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: part. Thine, in the dearest design of industry,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO.'

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Thus dost thou hear the Nemean lion roar

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: 'Gainst thee, thou lamb, that standest as his prey.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Submissive fall his princely feet before,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: And he from forage will incline to play:

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: But if thou strive, poor soul, what art thou then?

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Food for his rage, repasture for his den.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: What plume of feathers is he that indited this letter?

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: What vane? what weathercock? did you ever hear better?

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: I am much deceived but I remember the style.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Else your memory is bad, going o'er it erewhile.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: This Armado is a Spaniard, that keeps here in court;

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: A phantasime, a Monarcho, and one that makes sport

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: To the prince and his bookmates.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Thou fellow, a word:

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Who gave thee this letter?

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: I told you; my lord.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: To whom shouldst thou give it?

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: From my lord to my lady.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: From which lord to which lady?

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: From my lord Biron, a good master of mine,

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: To a lady of France that he call'd Rosaline.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Thou hast mistaken his letter. Come, lords, away.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: To ROSALINE

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Here, sweet, put up this: 'twill be thine another day.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Exeunt PRINCESS and train

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Who is the suitor? who is the suitor?

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Shall I teach you to know?

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Ay, my continent of beauty.

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Why, she that bears the bow.

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Finely put off!

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: My lady goes to kill horns; but, if thou marry,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Hang me by the neck, if horns that year miscarry.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Finely put on!

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Well, then, I am the shooter.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: And who is your deer?

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: If we choose by the horns, yourself come not near.

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Finely put on, indeed!

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: You still wrangle with her, Boyet, and she strikes

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: at the brow.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: But she herself is hit lower: have I hit her now?

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Shall I come upon thee with an old saying, that was

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: a man when King Pepin of France was a little boy, as

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: touching the hit it?

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: So I may answer thee with one as old, that was a

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: woman when Queen Guinover of Britain was a little

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: wench, as touching the hit it.

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Thou canst not hit it, hit it, hit it,

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Thou canst not hit it, my good man.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: An I cannot, cannot, cannot,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: An I cannot, another can.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Exeunt ROSALINE and KATHARINE

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: By my troth, most pleasant: how both did fit it!

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: A mark marvellous well shot, for they both did hit it.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: A mark! O, mark but that mark! A mark, says my lady!

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Let the mark have a prick in't, to mete at, if it may be.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Wide o' the bow hand! i' faith, your hand is out.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Indeed, a' must shoot nearer, or he'll ne'er hit the clout.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: An if my hand be out, then belike your hand is in.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Then will she get the upshoot by cleaving the pin.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Come, come, you talk greasily; your lips grow foul.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: She's too hard for you at pricks, sir: challenge her to bowl.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: I fear too much rubbing. Good night, my good owl.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Exeunt BOYET and MARIA

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: By my soul, a swain! a most simple clown!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Lord, Lord, how the ladies and I have put him down!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: O' my troth, most sweet jests! most incony

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: vulgar wit!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: When it comes so smoothly off, so obscenely, as it

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: were, so fit.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Armado o' th' one side,--O, a most dainty man!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: To see him walk before a lady and to bear her fan!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: To see him kiss his hand! and how most sweetly a'

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: will swear!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: And his page o' t' other side, that handful of wit!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Ah, heavens, it is a most pathetical nit!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Sola, sola!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Shout within

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Exit COSTARD, running

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: LOVE'S LABOURS LOST

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: SCENE II. The same.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Enter HOLOFERNES, SIR NATHANIEL, and DULL

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: Very reverend sport, truly; and done in the testimony

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: of a good conscience.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: The deer was, as you know, sanguis, in blood; ripe

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: as the pomewater, who now hangeth like a jewel in

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: the ear of caelo, the sky, the welkin, the heaven;

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: and anon falleth like a crab on the face of terra,

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: the soil, the land, the earth.

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: Truly, Master Holofernes, the epithets are sweetly

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: varied, like a scholar at the least: but, sir, I

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: assure ye, it was a buck of the first head.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: Sir Nathaniel, haud credo.

speaker: DULL
text_entry: 'Twas not a haud credo; 'twas a pricket.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: Most barbarous intimation! yet a kind of

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: insinuation, as it were, in via, in way, of

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: explication; facere, as it were, replication, or

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: rather, ostentare, to show, as it were, his

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: inclination, after his undressed, unpolished,

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: uneducated, unpruned, untrained, or rather,

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: unlettered, or ratherest, unconfirmed fashion, to

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: insert again my haud credo for a deer.

speaker: DULL
text_entry: I said the deer was not a haud credo; twas a pricket.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: Twice-sod simplicity, his coctus!

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: O thou monster Ignorance, how deformed dost thou look!

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: Sir, he hath never fed of the dainties that are bred

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: in a book; he hath not eat paper, as it were; he

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: hath not drunk ink: his intellect is not

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: replenished; he is only an animal, only sensible in

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: the duller parts:

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: And such barren plants are set before us, that we

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: thankful should be,

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: Which we of taste and feeling are, for those parts that

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: do fructify in us more than he.

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: For as it would ill become me to be vain, indiscreet, or a fool,

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: So were there a patch set on learning, to see him in a school:

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: But omne bene, say I; being of an old father's mind,

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: Many can brook the weather that love not the wind.

speaker: DULL
text_entry: You two are book-men: can you tell me by your wit

speaker: DULL
text_entry: What was a month old at Cain's birth, that's not five

speaker: DULL
text_entry: weeks old as yet?

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: Dictynna, goodman Dull; Dictynna, goodman Dull.

speaker: DULL
text_entry: What is Dictynna?

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: A title to Phoebe, to Luna, to the moon.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: The moon was a month old when Adam was no more,

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: And raught not to five weeks when he came to

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: five-score.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: The allusion holds in the exchange.

speaker: DULL
text_entry: 'Tis true indeed; the collusion holds in the exchange.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: God comfort thy capacity! I say, the allusion holds

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: in the exchange.

speaker: DULL
text_entry: And I say, the pollusion holds in the exchange; for

speaker: DULL
text_entry: the moon is never but a month old: and I say beside

speaker: DULL
text_entry: that, 'twas a pricket that the princess killed.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: Sir Nathaniel, will you hear an extemporal epitaph

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: on the death of the deer? And, to humour the

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: ignorant, call I the deer the princess killed a pricket.

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: Perge, good Master Holofernes, perge; so it shall

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: please you to abrogate scurrility.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: I will something affect the letter, for it argues facility.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: The preyful princess pierced and prick'd a pretty

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: pleasing pricket;

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: Some say a sore; but not a sore, till now made

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: sore with shooting.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: The dogs did yell: put L to sore, then sorel jumps

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: from thicket;

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: Or pricket sore, or else sorel; the people fall a-hooting.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: If sore be sore, then L to sore makes fifty sores

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: one sorel.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: Of one sore I an hundred make by adding but one more L.

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: A rare talent!

speaker: DULL
text_entry: [Aside]  If a talent be a claw, look how he claws

speaker: DULL
text_entry: him with a talent.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: This is a gift that I have, simple, simple; a

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: foolish extravagant spirit, full of forms, figures,

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: shapes, objects, ideas, apprehensions, motions,

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: revolutions: these are begot in the ventricle of

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: memory, nourished in the womb of pia mater, and

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: delivered upon the mellowing of occasion. But the

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: gift is good in those in whom it is acute, and I am

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: thankful for it.

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: Sir, I praise the Lord for you; and so may my

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: parishioners; for their sons are well tutored by

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: you, and their daughters profit very greatly under

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: you: you are a good member of the commonwealth.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: Mehercle, if their sons be ingenuous, they shall

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: want no instruction; if their daughters be capable,

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: I will put it to them: but vir sapit qui pauca

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: loquitur; a soul feminine saluteth us.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: Enter JAQUENETTA and COSTARD

speaker: JAQUENETTA
text_entry: God give you good morrow, master Parson.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: Master Parson, quasi pers-on. An if one should be

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: pierced, which is the one?

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Marry, master schoolmaster, he that is likest to a hogshead.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
text_entry: Piercing a hogshead! a good lustre of conceit in a

text_entry: If love make me forsworn, how shall I swear to love?

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: Ah, never faith could hold, if not to beauty vow'd!

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: Though to myself forsworn, to thee I'll faithful prove:

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: Those thoughts to me were oaks, to thee like

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: osiers bow'd.

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: Study his bias leaves and makes his book thine eyes,

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL

text_entry: comprehend:

text_entry: If knowledge be the mark, to know thee shall suffice;

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: Well learned is that tongue that well can thee commend,

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: All ignorant that soul that sees thee without wonder;

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: Which is to me some praise that I thy parts admire:

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: Thy eye Jove's lightning bears, thy voice his dreadful thunder,

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: Which not to anger bent, is music and sweet fire.

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: Celestial as thou art, O, pardon, love, this wrong,

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
text_entry: That sings heaven's praise with such an earthly tongue.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: word. Well, set thee down, sorrow! for so they say

speaker: BIRON

speaker: BIRON

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Ajax: it kills sheep; it kills me, I a sheep:

speaker: BIRON

speaker: BIRON

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: eye,--by this light, but for her eye, I would not

speaker: BIRON

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: in the world but lie, and lie in my throat. By

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: heaven, I do love: and it hath taught me to rhyme

speaker: BIRON

speaker: BIRON

speaker: BIRON

speaker: BIRON

text_entry: So sweet a kiss the golden sun gives not

speaker: FERDINAND

speaker: FERDINAND

speaker: FERDINAND

speaker: FERDINAND

speaker: FERDINAND

speaker: BIRON

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: That you three fools lack'd me fool to make up the mess:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: He, he, and you, and you, my liege, and I,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Are pick-purses in love, and we deserve to die.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: O, dismiss this audience, and I shall tell you more.

speaker: DUMAIN
text_entry: Now the number is even.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: True, true; we are four.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Will these turtles be gone?

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Hence, sirs; away!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Walk aside the true folk, and let the traitors stay.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Exeunt COSTARD and JAQUENETTA

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Sweet lords, sweet lovers, O, let us embrace!

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: As true we are as flesh and blood can be:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: The sea will ebb and flow, heaven show his face;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Young blood doth not obey an old decree:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: We cannot cross the cause why we were born;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Therefore of all hands must we be forsworn.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: What, did these rent lines show some love of thine?

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Did they, quoth you? Who sees the heavenly Rosaline,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: That, like a rude and savage man of Inde,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: At the first opening of the gorgeous east,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Bows not his vassal head and strucken blind

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Kisses the base ground with obedient breast?

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: What peremptory eagle-sighted eye

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Dares look upon the heaven of her brow,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: That is not blinded by her majesty?

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: What zeal, what fury hath inspired thee now?

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: My love, her mistress, is a gracious moon;

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: She an attending star, scarce seen a light.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: My eyes are then no eyes, nor I Biron:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: O, but for my love, day would turn to night!

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Of all complexions the cull'd sovereignty

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Do meet, as at a fair, in her fair cheek,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Where several worthies make one dignity,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Where nothing wants that want itself doth seek.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Lend me the flourish of all gentle tongues,--

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Fie, painted rhetoric! O, she needs it not:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: To things of sale a seller's praise belongs,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: She passes praise; then praise too short doth blot.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: A wither'd hermit, five-score winters worn,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Might shake off fifty, looking in her eye:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Beauty doth varnish age, as if new-born,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And gives the crutch the cradle's infancy:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: O, 'tis the sun that maketh all things shine.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: By heaven, thy love is black as ebony.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Is ebony like her? O wood divine!

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: A wife of such wood were felicity.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: O, who can give an oath? where is a book?

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: That I may swear beauty doth beauty lack,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: If that she learn not of her eye to look:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: No face is fair that is not full so black.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: O paradox! Black is the badge of hell,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: The hue of dungeons and the suit of night;

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: And beauty's crest becomes the heavens well.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Devils soonest tempt, resembling spirits of light.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: O, if in black my lady's brows be deck'd,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: It mourns that painting and usurping hair

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Should ravish doters with a false aspect;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And therefore is she born to make black fair.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Her favour turns the fashion of the days,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: For native blood is counted painting now;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And therefore red, that would avoid dispraise,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Paints itself black, to imitate her brow.

speaker: DUMAIN
text_entry: To look like her are chimney-sweepers black.

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: And since her time are colliers counted bright.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: And Ethiopes of their sweet complexion crack.

speaker: DUMAIN
text_entry: Dark needs no candles now, for dark is light.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Your mistresses dare never come in rain,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: For fear their colours should be wash'd away.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: 'Twere good, yours did; for, sir, to tell you plain,

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: I'll find a fairer face not wash'd to-day.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: I'll prove her fair, or talk till doomsday here.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: No devil will fright thee then so much as she.

speaker: DUMAIN
text_entry: I never knew man hold vile stuff so dear.

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: Look, here's thy love: my foot and her face see.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: O, if the streets were paved with thine eyes,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Her feet were much too dainty for such tread!

speaker: DUMAIN
text_entry: O, vile! then, as she goes, what upward lies

speaker: DUMAIN
text_entry: The street should see as she walk'd overhead.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: But what of this? are we not all in love?

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Nothing so sure; and thereby all forsworn.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Then leave this chat; and, good Biron, now prove

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Our loving lawful, and our faith not torn.

speaker: DUMAIN
text_entry: Ay, marry, there; some flattery for this evil.

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: O, some authority how to proceed;

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: Some tricks, some quillets, how to cheat the devil.

speaker: DUMAIN
text_entry: Some salve for perjury.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: 'Tis more than need.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Have at you, then, affection's men at arms.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Consider what you first did swear unto,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: To fast, to study, and to see no woman;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Flat treason 'gainst the kingly state of youth.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Say, can you fast? your stomachs are too young;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And abstinence engenders maladies.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And where that you have vow'd to study, lords,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: In that each of you have forsworn his book,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Can you still dream and pore and thereon look?

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: For when would you, my lord, or you, or you,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Have found the ground of study's excellence

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Without the beauty of a woman's face?

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: From women's eyes this doctrine I derive;  They are the ground, the books, the academes From whence doth spring the true Promethean fire

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Why, universal plodding poisons up

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: The nimble spirits in the arteries,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: As motion and long-during action tires

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: The sinewy vigour of the traveller.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Now, for not looking on a woman's face,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: You have in that forsworn the use of eyes

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And study too, the causer of your vow;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: For where is any author in the world

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Teaches such beauty as a woman's eye?

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Learning is but an adjunct to ourself

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And where we are our learning likewise is:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Then when ourselves we see in ladies' eyes,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Do we not likewise see our learning there?

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: O, we have made a vow to study, lords,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And in that vow we have forsworn our books.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: For when would you, my liege, or you, or you,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: In leaden contemplation have found out

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Such fiery numbers as the prompting eyes

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Of beauty's tutors have enrich'd you with?

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Other slow arts entirely keep the brain;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And therefore, finding barren practisers,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Scarce show a harvest of their heavy toil:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: But love, first learned in a lady's eyes,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Lives not alone immured in the brain;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: But, with the motion of all elements,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Courses as swift as thought in every power,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And gives to every power a double power,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Above their functions and their offices.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: It adds a precious seeing to the eye;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: A lover's eyes will gaze an eagle blind;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: A lover's ear will hear the lowest sound,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: When the suspicious head of theft is stopp'd:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Love's feeling is more soft and sensible

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Than are the tender horns of cockl'd snails;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Love's tongue proves dainty Bacchus gross in taste:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: For valour, is not Love a Hercules,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Still climbing trees in the Hesperides?

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Subtle as Sphinx; as sweet and musical

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: As bright Apollo's lute, strung with his hair:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And when Love speaks, the voice of all the gods

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Makes heaven drowsy with the harmony.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Never durst poet touch a pen to write

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Until his ink were temper'd with Love's sighs;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: O, then his lines would ravish savage ears

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And plant in tyrants mild humility.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: From women's eyes this doctrine I derive:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: They sparkle still the right Promethean fire;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: They are the books, the arts, the academes,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: That show, contain and nourish all the world:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Else none at all in ought proves excellent.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Then fools you were these women to forswear,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Or keeping what is sworn, you will prove fools.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: For wisdom's sake, a word that all men love,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Or for love's sake, a word that loves all men,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Or for men's sake, the authors of these women,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Or women's sake, by whom we men are men,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Let us once lose our oaths to find ourselves,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Or else we lose ourselves to keep our oaths.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: It is religion to be thus forsworn,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: For charity itself fulfills the law,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And who can sever love from charity?

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Saint Cupid, then! and, soldiers, to the field!

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Advance your standards, and upon them, lords;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Pell-mell, down with them! but be first advised,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: In conflict that you get the sun of them.

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: Now to plain-dealing; lay these glozes by:

speaker: LONGAVILLE
text_entry: Shall we resolve to woo these girls of France?

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: And win them too: therefore let us devise

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Some entertainment for them in their tents.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: First, from the park let us conduct them thither;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Then homeward every man attach the hand

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Of his fair mistress: in the afternoon

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: We will with some strange pastime solace them,

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Such as the shortness of the time can shape;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: For revels, dances, masks and merry hours

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Forerun fair Love, strewing her way with flowers.

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: Away, away! no time shall be omitted

speaker: FERDINAND
text_entry: That will betime, and may by us be fitted.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Allons! allons! Sow'd cockle reap'd no corn;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: And justice always whirls in equal measure:

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Light wenches may prove plagues to men forsworn;

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: If so, our copper buys no better treasure.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: LOVE'S LABOURS LOST

text_entry: Joshua, yourself; myself and this gallant gentleman,
